She talks in bullet points: sponsor expectations, possible media questions, your role.

Then, without looking up, she says:

‘If someone tries to make my name a headline, I will end it.’

It isn’t jealousy.

It’s control — and a warning that she cares enough to be careful.

choices.text: Promise discretion and competence. Keep the boundary intact.
Ask what she’s afraid of losing (personal question, risky timing).

c9_kira_pre_edge.label: Chapter Nine
c9_kira_pre_edge.title: The One Sentence That Slips
c9_kira_pre_edge.text:
Kira’s fingers pause on the trackpad.

For a second, she looks younger — not softer, just unguarded.

‘I’m afraid,’ she says quietly, ‘of being reduced.’

Then she closes her laptop like the confession never happened.

‘Let’s go.’

choices.text: Don’t push further. Respect what she offered.
Push anyway: tell her she’s more than her job (tender, but could irritate).

c9_jannah_pre.label: Chapter Nine
c9_jannah_pre.title: Glitter, Glue, and Gratitude
c9_jannah_pre.text:
Jannah’s classroom smells like paper and sweet milk.

She’s surrounded by tiny hands making ‘thank you’ cards for nurses and doctors.

When you show up, she doesn’t say ‘you came.’

She just hands you a stack of stickers like you’ve always belonged here.

Later, in a lull, she murmurs:

‘You’re good with pressure. But I wonder if you’re good with staying.’

choices.text: Tell her you’re trying to learn staying — not just showing up.
Joke it off and change the subject (safe, but costs something).

c9_xinyi_pre.label: Chapter Nine
c9_xinyi_pre.title: No Audience, No Escape
c9_xinyi_pre.text:
Xin Yi chooses a quiet supper spot — somewhere the noise can’t hide you.

She doesn’t interrogate.

She observes.

‘I don’t need to win,’ she says. ‘I need to know I’m not being used as a resting place between your storms.’

Her voice stays calm, but the sentence lands like a blade with a velvet handle.

choices.text: Be specific: name a plan for tonight, and for after tonight.
Ask her to just ‘be patient’ (a request that sounds like entitlement).

c9_dasha_pre.label: Chapter Nine
c9_dasha_pre.title: Layover Light
c9_dasha_pre.text:
Changi feels like a city that never sleeps.

Dasha meets you by a glass wall, suitcase at her feet, hair slightly damp from travel.

She grins like she’s pretending this is casual.

‘I’m not Vietnamese,’ she reminds you again, amused. ‘Kazakhstan. Still Kazakhstan.’

Then she tilts her head.

‘Tell me the truth. Do you miss me — or do you miss being brave?’

choices.text: Tell her you miss her specifically — the person, not the adrenaline.
Keep it poetic but vague (pretty words, low clarity).

c9_almah_pre.label: Chapter Nine
c9_almah_pre.title: Before the Crowd
c9_almah_pre.text:
Hospitals at dusk feel like a different kind of city.

Almahirah steps out for five minutes — not more. Her lanyard swings, her eyes steady.

She looks at you the way she looked ten years ago when she already knew the answer.

‘Don’t make tonight a performance,’ she says. ‘If you care, care with discipline.’

Then, softer:

‘And don’t make other women pay for mistakes you made with me.’

choices.text: Agree — and ask what ‘discipline’ looks like in practice.
Get defensive (pride reflex).

c9_almah_pre_detail.label: Chapter Nine
c9_almah_pre_detail.title: Discipline
c9_almah_pre_detail.text:
Almahirah doesn’t raise her voice.

She lists it like a care plan:

• Don’t lie to make life easier.
• Don’t flirt to collect comfort.
• Don’t promise what you won’t keep.

‘You’re older now,’ she says. ‘Act like it.’

Then she nods once and returns to the ward — mercy done quietly, without applause.

choices.text: Let it humble you. Walk into the night more careful than you were.
Tell yourself she’s being unfair (and carry that irritation into the event).

c9_event_arrival.label: Chapter Nine
c9_event_arrival.title: Mercy Night: Same Room
c9_event_arrival.text:
The venue is inside the hospital’s fundraiser hall — soft lighting, polite laughter, donation screens.

You enter and immediately feel it:

Kira near the sponsor backdrop, posture perfect.
Jannah guiding her preschool team with a box of handmade cards.
Xin Yi with your close friend group, watching the room like she’s mapping risk.
Almahirah moving through staff corridors, visible only in glimpses.
And Dasha — unexpectedly here — a green dot on your phone that says she made it past immigration.

There is no way to be everywhere.

So the question becomes: who do you stand beside first — when it’s public?

choices.text: Go to Kira at the sponsor wall (public alignment).
Help Jannah with the kids’ cards (service first).
Join Xin Yi and your friend group (belonging + optics).
Slip outside to greet Dasha (rare window, risky timing).
Find Almahirah in the staff corridor (private accountability).

c9_event_kira_wall.label: Chapter Nine
c9_event_kira_wall.title: Sponsor Backdrop
c9_event_kira_wall.text:
Kira turns as you approach.

Her gaze flicks over your outfit — approving, assessing.

A camera flash pops.

Then Xin Yi appears from your friend group’s side, pausing like she didn’t expect this angle.

She doesn’t interrupt.

She just watches.

Kira, without looking away from the lens, murmurs:

‘If you’re going to stand here, stand properly.’

choices.text: Introduce Xin Yi to Kira openly (no hiding).
Pretend you didn’t see Xin Yi (avoidance becomes visible).
Excuse yourself to check on Jannah’s group (balance, but looks like retreat).

c9_event_kira_xinyi_intro.label: Chapter Nine
c9_event_kira_xinyi_intro.title: Two Worlds Shaking Hands
c9_event_kira_xinyi_intro.text:
You bring Xin Yi over.

Kira’s smile is polite, professional.

Xin Yi’s is warm, controlled.

They exchange names, roles, harmless facts.

But the subtext is clear:

One is your boss.

One is your home.

And you are the unstable bridge.

choices.text: Stay with Kira for the sponsor segment (commit to the optics you started).
Step away with Xin Yi to decompress (repair her nerves).

c9_event_kira_avoid.label: Chapter Nine
c9_event_kira_avoid.title: The Avoidance She Can See
c9_event_kira_avoid.text:
You keep your body angled toward the sponsor wall.

You pretend you didn’t notice Xin Yi.

But silence is a sound.

When the flash fades, Kira says quietly:

‘You’re distracted.’

And behind her, Xin Yi turns away like she’s finally tired of being reasonable.

choices.text: Chase Xin Yi immediately (repair first).
Stay with Kira and finish the sponsor segment (don’t make a bigger mess).

c9_event_jannah_cards.label: Chapter Nine
c9_event_jannah_cards.title: The Card Table
c9_event_jannah_cards.text:
Jannah is kneeling to help a child write ‘thank you’ in shaky letters.

You take the box and start sorting cards by ward.

She looks up — relief again, the quiet kind.

Then Dasha appears at the edge of the hall, scanning for you.

She spots you with Jannah.

Her smile doesn’t drop.

It sharpens.

choices.text: Introduce Dasha to Jannah (honest, brave).
Ask Dasha to wait outside (postpone collision).
Stay focused on the kids and ignore the tension (service as escape).

c9_jannah_dasha_intro.label: Chapter Nine
c9_jannah_dasha_intro.title: Mist Meets Warmth
c9_jannah_dasha_intro.text:
Dasha shakes Jannah’s hand.

Jannah’s smile is gracious.

Dasha’s is curious.

They exchange a few sentences — travel, work, Singapore humidity.

Then Dasha turns to you and says, softly:

‘So this is who you feel safe with.’

Jannah hears it.

She doesn’t react.

But her eyes do.

choices.text: Defuse it: praise both of them without comparing (careful language).
Let the tension hang (you’re tired of managing).

c9_dasha_outside_wait.label: Chapter Nine
c9_dasha_outside_wait.title: Outside the Hall
c9_dasha_outside_wait.text:
You step out to find Dasha near the glass doors.

She’s smiling, but it doesn’t reach her eyes.

‘You asked me to wait,’ she says. ‘Like I’m a secret.’

Her tone is light.

The meaning isn’t.

choices.text: Apologize properly and bring her back in (undo the ‘secret’ feeling).
Double down: keep it separate for tonight (control, but hurts).

c9_event_xinyi_group.label: Chapter Nine
c9_event_xinyi_group.title: Friend Group Gravity
c9_event_xinyi_group.text:
Xin Yi stands with your close friends, laughing at something you half-missed.

It feels normal.

Normal is dangerous.

Because normal is where you’re most tempted to stop being deliberate.

Halfway through the conversation, Kira approaches — sponsor badge, professional smile.

She greets your group like it’s part of her job.

Xin Yi’s posture tightens a fraction.

choices.text: Introduce Kira as your boss, cleanly (no weirdness).
Overcompensate with jokes (makes it feel suspicious).
Excuse yourself to help Jannah (escape the triangle).

c9_xinyi_kira_clean_intro.label: Chapter Nine
c9_xinyi_kira_clean_intro.title: Clean Lines
c9_xinyi_kira_clean_intro.text:
You keep it simple.

Boss. Team. Work.

Kira nods like she respects clarity.

Xin Yi watches like she’s checking whether your honesty is consistent.

Then a volunteer announces the donation tally.

Applause.

Noise.

And in the noise, your phone buzzes — Almahirah: *‘Ward 7 needs extra hands. Five minutes.’*

choices.text: Go help Almahirah (service in private).
Stay with Xin Yi through the program (choose the personal over duty).

c9_xinyi_kira_joke.label: Chapter Nine
c9_xinyi_kira_joke.title: Jokes That Smell Like Smoke
c9_xinyi_kira_joke.text:
You make a joke.

It lands.

But jokes are not neutral.

Xin Yi smiles — politely.

Kira’s eyes narrow — slightly.

You feel it: both of them sensing you’re trying to manage perception instead of telling the truth.

choices.text: Correct yourself: stop joking and clarify, properly.
Keep joking (avoid discomfort; create quiet damage).

c9_event_dasha_arrival.label: Chapter Nine
c9_event_dasha_arrival.title: Transit Woman
c9_event_dasha_arrival.text:
You find Dasha outside the hall.

She’s holding a small paper cup of water like it’s a travel ritual.

‘Singapore again,’ she says. ‘Your city likes to test people.’

From the glass doors, you can see the sponsor backdrop.

Kira is there.

Xin Yi is there.

Dasha follows your gaze and says, lightly:

‘You live a complicated life for someone who pretends he hates drama.’

choices.text: Bring Dasha inside and introduce her (honest, chaotic).
Keep Dasha outside for a private talk (1-on-1, but secrecy risk).

c9_event_dasha_inside.label: Chapter Nine
c9_event_dasha_inside.title: The Introduction You Can’t Unmake
c9_event_dasha_inside.text:
You bring Dasha in.

Her presence changes the room — not loud, just different.

Xin Yi clocks it immediately.

Kira clocks it because she clocks everything.

Jannah looks up from the card table and offers a smile that’s kind enough to hurt.

For one second, you feel like you’re holding five fragile plates with one hand.

And the night hasn’t even reached the speeches.

choices.text: Stand near Jannah and the kids (choose gentleness; signal priorities).
Return to Kira’s sponsor area (control the optics).
Stay with Xin Yi’s group (repair the closest thread).

c9_dasha_private_talk.label: Chapter Nine
c9_dasha_private_talk.title: Five Minutes of Truth
c9_dasha_private_talk.text:
You and Dasha stand near the quiet corridor where the air-conditioning hums.

She asks about your life.

Not the ‘what do you do’ version.

The ‘who are you becoming’ version.

And when you answer, you realize you’re answering yourself too.

Then, through the glass, you see Xin Yi glance outside.

She sees you.

Her expression changes — not anger.

Recognition.

choices.text: Go to Xin Yi immediately and explain (repair the optics).
Stay with Dasha until she has to go (choose the rare window).

c9_event_almah_corridor.label: Chapter Nine
c9_event_almah_corridor.title: Staff Corridor
c9_event_almah_corridor.text:
You find Almahirah near the staff corridor.

No makeup. No performance. Just fatigue and focus.

She hands you gloves.

‘Five minutes,’ she says. ‘Then go back to your life.’

You help settle something small — water, a blanket, a calm voice.

When you’re done, she looks at you and says:

‘This is who you are when no one is clapping.’

It sounds like praise.

It also sounds like a test.

choices.text: Stay a little longer (risk the event; choose service).
Return to the hall immediately (balance duty + optics).

c9_almah_longer.label: Chapter Nine
c9_almah_longer.title: Quiet Work
c9_almah_longer.text:
You stay.

It’s not romantic.

It’s just real.

When Almahirah finally nods you out, you pass the glass doors and see the sponsor wall again.

A photo is being taken.

Kira glances toward you.

Xin Yi’s friend group is watching.

And you realize: choosing mercy has consequences too.

choices.text: Return to Kira’s side (repair the sponsor optics).
Find Xin Yi and be transparent (repair the personal optics).
Go back to Jannah’s table and help (choose softness again).

c9_xinyi_sidehall.label: Chapter Nine
c9_xinyi_sidehall.title: Side Hall Conversation
c9_xinyi_sidehall.text:
Xin Yi doesn’t raise her voice.

She doesn’t need to.

‘I’m watching you,’ she says. ‘Not to police you — to decide if your honesty is real or seasonal.’

She takes a breath.

‘Tell me now: do you want me, or do you want my comfort?’

choices.text: Choose honesty with cost: admit you want her, but you’ve been afraid of committing.
Choose control: keep it vague and ‘safe’ (she will feel it).
Choose discipline: tell her you won’t flirt with anyone else tonight (temporary boundary).

c9_mid_hub.label: Chapter Nine
c9_mid_hub.title: After the Speeches
c9_mid_hub.text:
The speeches end.

Donation numbers rise.

People clap.

And somewhere between applause and polite smiles, you realize the night is not about money.

It’s about exposure.

Everyone has seen enough to start forming conclusions.

Now you get one more move — not public.

Private.

One-on-one.

And the way you choose will echo into the endings.

choices.text: Find Kira for a quiet talk about boundaries and what this costs both of you.
Walk Jannah to her car and let the softness become honest.
Sit with Xin Yi and your friend group — show consistency in the place that feels like home.
Give Dasha the goodbye she deserves before her next flight.
Check on Almahirah after her shift and face the ten-year scar properly.
Do something reckless: try to keep everyone close (creates unnecessary tension).

c9_kira_private.label: Chapter Nine
c9_kira_private.title: Kira: The Cost of Being Seen
c9_kira_private.text:
You find Kira near the service corridor, away from cameras.

She exhales like she’s been holding breath for hours.

‘Tonight is not romantic,’ she says.

Then she looks at you.

‘So don’t make it cheap.’

In her language, that is a confession.

choices.text: Answer in her language: promise discretion and long-term consistency.
Cross the line: reach for her hand in a place with risk (thrill, but dangerous).
Step back: keep it strictly professional (safety over intimacy).

c9_jannah_private.label: Chapter Nine
c9_jannah_private.title: Jannah: The Slow Home
c9_jannah_private.text:
Outside, the air is warm and damp.

Jannah carries the leftover cards like they’re fragile.

She pauses by her car and finally says:

‘I don’t need grand gestures.
I need you to stop making me guess where I stand.’

Her eyes are gentle.

Her request is not.

choices.text: Tell her she’s not an option — she’s a direction (brave clarity).
Ask for time again (repeating an old pattern).
Be honest without romance: say you care deeply, but you’re not ready to promise (respectful, still painful).

c9_xinyi_private.label: Chapter Nine
c9_xinyi_private.title: Xin Yi: The Place You Return To
c9_xinyi_private.text:
You sit with Xin Yi and your close friend group.

This is where you usually hide — laughter, normal conversation, the illusion that life is simple.

Xin Yi leans in and whispers:

‘If you want me, you can’t keep me as your ‘default’ while you audition other lives.’

The sentence is quiet.

It cuts anyway.

choices.text: Commit to a defined season: ask her for one month exclusive, with clear rules.
Confess fear: you want her but you’re scared of losing the friendship if it fails.
Avoid direction (she will hear it).

c9_dasha_private.label: Chapter Nine
c9_dasha_private.title: Dasha: The Goodbye That Matters
c9_dasha_private.text:
Dasha checks her phone.

Boarding time.

She smiles like she’s practiced leaving.

‘I don’t want to be a souvenir,’ she says.

‘If you want me, want me like you want a real life — not like you want a story to tell.’

choices.text: Give her honesty: tell her you’ll visit Sapa again, with a date — not a fantasy.
Give her romance without commitment (beautiful, hollow).
Let her go with respect: thank her for the courage she pulled out of you.

c9_almah_private.label: Chapter Nine
c9_almah_private.title: Almahirah: Ten Years in One Conversation
c9_almah_private.text:
Almahirah’s shift ends late.

She washes her hands, then meets you by a quiet bench outside the staff exit.

She doesn’t ask if you missed her.

She asks:

‘Are you still the man who runs when things get serious?’

The question isn’t cruel.

It’s necessary.

choices.text: Own the past: apologize specifically for how you ended it ten years ago.
Try to rewrite history (minimize your fault).
Ask for a second chance carefully — not a romance, but a conversation that continues.

c9_reckless_choice.label: Chapter Nine
c9_reckless_choice.title: Unnecessary Tension
c9_reckless_choice.text:
You do something you know is stupid.

You try to keep everyone close.

A half-truth here.
A reassuring line there.

It works for five minutes — and then it starts to fail.

Kira notices the inconsistencies.

Xin Yi notices the emotional math.

Jannah notices the way you look tired of being honest.

Dasha notices because she’s a traveller — she can smell exits.

Almahirah notices because she’s a nurse — she can smell denial.

The night becomes sharper.

Not because they’re fighting.

Because they’re deciding.

choices.text: Stop. Choose one person to be honest with tonight (and accept the others will feel it).
Keep juggling (further tension, small ‘wins’ that cost trust).

c9_end.label: Chapter Nine
c9_end.title: End of Chapter Nine
c9_end.text:
By the time the hall empties, you understand something you avoided for months:

Choosing isn’t about intensity.

It’s about consistency.

The endings won’t ask who you *wanted*.

They’ll ask who you were brave enough to be.

choices.text: Continue to the Finale gate.

c10_start.label: Chapter Ten
c10_start.title: The Night Everything Touches
c10_start.text:
The city feels too small for five stories at once.

You don’t plan the meeting.
You just choose a place that can hold a conclusion without demanding a spectacle: a quiet waterfront spot where the lights don’t judge you.

You send five messages. Not invitations. Not pleas.
A simple line:

“Tonight, I’ll be honest.”

Some replies come fast.
Some come late.
One comes with only a read receipt.

Chapter Ten begins with the first step you’ve avoided since Chapter One:
you stop trying to keep the same version of you in every room.

choices.text: Start with a one-on-one: meet Xin Yi first before anyone arrives.
Start with a one-on-one: meet Jannah first and let her set the emotional tone.
Start with a one-on-one: meet Kira first and face the work-personal line.
Start with a one-on-one: meet Almahirah first — the past you never finished.
Start with a one-on-one: call Dasha first — the window that keeps moving.

c10_xinyi_pre.label: Chapter Ten
c10_xinyi_pre.title: Xin Yi — The Friend Who Stayed
c10_xinyi_pre.text:
Xin Yi arrives early.

She doesn’t look angry.
She looks *tired of being brave for you*.

“You called everyone,” she says.

You nod.

She watches your face like she’s reading whether you’ll flinch.

“If you’re going to end this,” she says quietly, “end it clean. No warmth that keeps me hoping.”

choices.text: Promise clean honesty, even if it costs you.
Try to soften it with jokes (unnecessary tension).

c10_jannah_pre.label: Chapter Ten
c10_jannah_pre.title: Jannah — The Kind of Love That Holds
c10_jannah_pre.text:
Jannah arrives with careful steps, like she’s walking into a room that might reject her.

She smiles politely.
Then she drops the smile.

“I don’t want to fight anyone,” she says. “I just want to know if I’m wasting my heart.”

Her voice is soft.
Her boundary isn’t.

choices.text: Reassure her with action: give her your phone and tell her you’ll be present tonight.
Keep your phone (unnecessary tension): ‘I might need it for work.’

c10_kira_pre.label: Chapter Ten
c10_kira_pre.title: Kira — The Line That Cuts
c10_kira_pre.text:
Kira arrives last among the early ones.

She looks at the place, then at you.

“This is personal,” she says, as if naming the danger makes it manageable.

You nod.

She doesn’t step closer.

“If you’re choosing chaos,” she says, “don’t drag my career into it.”

choices.text: Acknowledge the risk and set boundaries: ‘I won’t use you, professionally or emotionally.’
Flirt anyway (unnecessary tension): blur the line in public.

c10_almah_pre.label: Chapter Ten
c10_almah_pre.title: Almahirah — Ten Years Ago, Still Here
c10_almah_pre.text:
Almahirah stands a few steps away from you, not too close.

The ex you dated a decade ago.

In Mecca, fate didn’t give you romance.
It gave you *a mirror*.

“Don’t make this sacred into a drama,” she says.

Not cold.
Just honest.

choices.text: Ask for closure: ‘If I choose someone else, I want you to be free of me.’
Make her ‘the backup’ (unnecessary tension): keep the door half-open.

c10_dasha_pre.label: Chapter Ten
c10_dasha_pre.title: Dasha — The Horizon
c10_dasha_pre.text:
Dasha doesn’t show up.

She calls.

The camera shakes a little. Wind. Night.

“I can’t stay,” she says, like she hates that it’s true.

“But I needed to hear what you are when you’re forced to be real.”

She pauses.

“If you choose someone… choose her like you chose the sunrise. Like you meant it.”

choices.text: Promise to be real tonight and ask her to wait for the outcome.
Beg her to come anyway (unnecessary tension): turn it into pressure.

c10_group_arrival.label: Chapter Ten
c10_group_arrival.title: When Worlds Overlap
c10_group_arrival.text:
They arrive in layers.

A familiar face at the edge of the lights.
A pause when someone recognizes someone else.
A second too long of silence.

No one screams.
No one claims you.

That’s what makes it worse.

They are all waiting for the same thing:

not your feelings—

your *decision-making*.

You clear your throat.

“I’m done being vague,” you say.

The night holds its breath.

choices.text: Do it clean: speak one name, then release the rest with respect.
Do it messy (unnecessary tension): ‘I care about all of you.’
Try to postpone again: ‘I need more time.’

c10_commit_pick.label: Chapter Ten
c10_commit_pick.title: Say the Name
c10_commit_pick.text:
You could still dodge.

You could still optimize.

But the room is done with that version of you.

You inhale.

And you say a name.

choices.text: Choose Kira.
Choose Jannah.
Choose Dasha.
Choose Xin Yi.
Choose Almahirah.

c10_messy_fallout.label: Chapter Ten
c10_messy_fallout.title: The Sentence That Breaks It
c10_messy_fallout.text:
“I care about all of you.”

It lands like a stone.

Not romantic.
Not flattering.

A refusal to choose disguised as kindness.

You watch it happen:

Xin Yi’s shoulders harden.
Jannah’s eyes go glassy.
Kira’s expression empties.
Almahirah looks away like she’s disappointed in herself for hoping.

And Dasha’s voice message comes in, late:

“Don’t do that. Don’t make women carry your indecision.”

choices.text: Recover: choose one name now (salvage what you can).
Let the fallout stand (accept the consequence).

c10_walkaway.label: Chapter Ten
c10_walkaway.title: More Time
c10_walkaway.text:
You ask for more time.

No one yells.

That’s how you know you lost something.

Kira nods once, already emotionally gone.

Jannah smiles politely, like a teacher managing disappointment.

Xin Yi whispers, “Okay.” The kind of okay that ends a chapter.

Almahirah’s gaze softens with mercy—then closes.

And your phone buzzes.

Dasha: “Then you were never real.”

choices.text: Chase one person (panic choice).
Let them go and face the finale alone.

c10_panic_pick.label: Chapter Ten
c10_panic_pick.title: Running After a Door
c10_panic_pick.text:
You move on instinct.

But instinct isn’t the same as love.

You can follow one person now.

The others will notice.

And the night will remember.

choices.text: Run after Xin Yi.
Run after Jannah.
Run after Kira.
Run after Almahirah.
Call Dasha immediately.

c10_after_kira.label: Chapter Ten
c10_after_kira.title: After: Kira
c10_after_kira.text:
Kira doesn’t soften instantly.

She looks at the others, then back at you.

“This can’t be half,” she says.

You nod.

She doesn’t smile.

But she steps closer.

And that is her version of forgiveness.

The rest of the night isn’t dramatic.

It’s quiet.

You speak to the others one by one.

You don’t keep them warm.

You let them go properly.

choices.text: Go to the finale.

c10_after_jannah.label: Chapter Ten
c10_after_jannah.title: After: Jannah
c10_after_jannah.text:
Jannah’s eyes fill—but she doesn’t cry.

She just breathes, like she’s been holding it for weeks.

“Okay,” she whispers.

You can tell she doesn’t believe in perfect love.

She believes in the kind that shows up.

So you do.

You speak to the others gently.

Not apologizing for loving her.

Apologizing for being unclear.

choices.text: Go to the finale.

c10_after_dasha.label: Chapter Ten
c10_after_dasha.title: After: Dasha
c10_after_dasha.text:
You don’t get a dramatic kiss.

You get a long exhale.

A laugh that shakes.

A quiet, stunned line:

“So you *can* be real.”

Dasha doesn’t promise forever.

She promises honesty.

And for now, that feels like the bravest thing.

You talk to the others with respect.

You don’t keep doors open.

You close them gently.

choices.text: Go to the finale.

c10_after_xinyi.label: Chapter Ten
c10_after_xinyi.title: After: Xin Yi
c10_after_xinyi.text:
Xin Yi doesn’t look triumphant.

She looks relieved.

Like she finally knows what to do with her heart.

“You’ll have to live up to that,” she says.

You nod.

And for once, you don’t try to negotiate.

You speak to the others.

You don’t plead.

You respect them.

And that respect becomes the first real proof that you’ve changed.

choices.text: Go to the finale.

c10_after_almah.label: Chapter Ten
c10_after_almah.title: After: Almahirah
c10_after_almah.text:
Almahirah’s gaze steadies.

“You’re choosing me,” she says, almost like she’s testing whether the sentence is true.

Ten years ago, you were younger.

You loved like a boy who wanted comfort.

Tonight, if you choose her, you must choose her like a man who understands what he once broke.

She nods once.

Not romance.

A covenant.

Then you speak to the others, with respect.

No half-doors.

No borrowed warmth.

choices.text: Go to the finale.

c10_to_finale.label: Chapter Ten
c10_to_finale.title: The Door to the Finale
c10_to_finale.text:
Chapter Ten doesn’t end with fireworks.

It ends with honesty finally doing what it was supposed to do:

it creates consequences that feel *clean*.

Whatever happens next is no longer about confusion.

It’s about the ending you earned.

choices.text: Step into the finale.
